Progressive summarization is Tiago Forte’s method for extracting value from notes over time. Instead of processing everything upfront, you distill notes progressively as you use them.
The Layers Each pass adds a layer of highlighting:
Layer 0: Original content (capture) Layer 1: Bold the most interesting passages Layer 2: Highlight the bolded passages that stand out Layer 3: Write a brief summary at the top Layer 4: Remix into your own original content
You don’t apply all layers immediately. Each layer is added when you revisit the note for a specific purpose.
Just-in-Time Processing The key insight: don’t process notes until you need them. Most captured content is never used. Progressive summarization ensures you only invest effort in notes that prove valuable.
This connects to [[Spaced Repetition]]: each revisit is an opportunity for both review and distillation.
Relationship to Zettelkasten Progressive summarization is compatible with the [[The Atomic Notes Principle|atomic notes principle]]. As you distill a note to its essence, you might extract multiple atomic notes from the highlights.
It bridges the gap between quick capture and [[Evergreen Notes]]:
Capture quickly (fleeting notes) Progressively distill over time Extract permanent atomic notes when insights crystallize Practical Application Start with Layer 1 on everything you capture. Add deeper layers only when you return to a note. Let future you decide what’s truly valuable.
See [[How to Take Smart Notes]] for the original Zettelkasten approach that influenced this method.
title: Progressive Summarization

contents:
Spaced repetition is a learning technique based on the spacing effect: we remember things better when we review them at increasing intervals rather than cramming.
The Science When you learn something new, the memory decays over time. Each review strengthens the memory and slows the decay rate. By timing reviews just before you’d forget, you maximize retention with minimum effort.
The optimal intervals follow a pattern:
First review: 1 day Second review: 3 days Third review: 7 days Fourth review: 14 days And so on, roughly doubling each time Application to Note-Taking Spaced repetition complements [[Evergreen Notes]] naturally. Each time you revisit a note to add links or refine content, you’re reinforcing that knowledge.
The [[Note-Taking|knowledge graph]] can guide your reviews. Notes with many connections are naturally reviewed more often as you traverse the graph. Orphan notes might need deliberate scheduling.
Tools and Systems Dedicated SRS tools like Anki automate interval scheduling. But even without special software, the principle applies:
Revisit notes periodically Use daily notes to reference older concepts Let curiosity guide exploratory sessions Connection to Writing Writing itself is a form of retrieval practice. When you write about a concept in your own words, you’re testing and strengthening your understanding.
See [[Progressive Summarization]] for a method that naturally incorporates spaced review.
title: Spaced Repetition

Bidirectional linking means that when note A links to note B, note B automatically knows about and displays the connection back to A. This simple mechanism transforms how we navigate and discover knowledge.
Why Backlinks Matter Traditional links are one-way streets. You know where you’re going, but you can’t see where you came from. Backlinks complete the picture.
Consider a note about “Machine Learning”. Without backlinks, you only see what ML links to. With backlinks, you discover:
Projects that use ML Problems ML might solve Related concepts you’ve explored This serendipitous discovery is impossible with one-way links.
Enabling Discovery Backlinks surface unexpected connections. When you create a note about a new concept and see it already has backlinks, you’ve discovered relationships you didn’t consciously make.
This is the essence of networked thought: the whole becomes greater than the sum of its parts.
Implementation In this system, backlinks appear automatically at the bottom of each note. They show:
The linking note’s title Context around the link A direct path to explore further Foundation for Graphs Bidirectional links enable the [[Note-Taking|knowledge graph visualization]]. Each bidirectional link becomes an edge in the graph, making your knowledge structure visible and navigable.
See also:
[[The Atomic Notes Principle]] - Makes links precise [[Evergreen Notes]] - Accumulates links over time

contents:
The knowledge graph visualizes connections between notes. It turns the abstract idea of “linked thinking” into something you can see and explore.
Why Visualize? Our brains are visual. A list of backlinks tells you what connects, but a graph shows you how the connections form patterns.
Try It Open the full-page graph to explore. Drag nodes, filter by section, toggle link types. How It Works The graph uses D3.js force simulation. Each note becomes a node; each link becomes an edge.
const simulation = d3.forceSimulation(nodes) .force('link', d3.forceLink(links).id(d => d.id)) .force('charge', d3.forceManyBody().strength(-200)) .force('center', d3.forceCenter(width / 2, height / 2)); Nodes repel each other (charge force) while links pull connected nodes together. The result is a layout where clusters naturally emerge.
Two Types of Edges The graph shows two kinds of connections:
Direct links (solid blue): Explicit wikilinks between notes. These are intentional connections you create.
Tag connections (dashed gray): Notes sharing the same tag. These are implicit - they suggest possible relationships you might not have noticed.
Technical Detail: Edge Detection Direct links are detected by scanning note content for [[...]] patterns and wikilink shortcodes. This happens at build time, so the graph data is static and fast to load.
{{- $bracketMatches := findRE `\[\[([^\]|]+)` $content -}} Reading the Graph Clusters indicate related concepts. The [[Note-Taking]] and [[Learning]] nodes should be close together, connected by shared notes.
Hubs are highly-connected nodes. MOCs like [[Note-Taking]] naturally become hubs because they link to many notes.
Bridges connect different clusters. A note that links learning concepts to technical implementations bridges those domains.
Filtering The full-page graph offers controls to:
Show/hide sections (articles, notes, projects) Toggle direct links vs tag connections Search for specific notes Zoom in on details This makes large graphs manageable while preserving the overall structure.
Limitations The graph is a model, not reality. It shows explicit connections but not the implicit understanding in your head.
Use it as a tool for discovery, not a measure of knowledge completeness.
Building Your Own The graph is generated entirely in Hugo templates. No external build step required. Check the theme’s partials/graph.html for implementation details.
See [[Bidirectional Linking]] for why the connections matter more than the visualization itself.

Evergreen notes are notes designed to grow and improve over time. Unlike fleeting captures or project-specific documentation, evergreen notes are investments in your future thinking.
Characteristics Concept-oriented: Written about ideas, not sources or events. A note titled “Spaced Repetition” is evergreen; “Notes from Chapter 3” is not.
Densely linked: Connected to many other notes, forming a web of knowledge. Each new connection adds context and value.
Written for yourself: In your own words, reflecting your understanding. Not quotes or summaries, but synthesis.
The Compound Effect Like compound interest, evergreen notes become more valuable over time:
Each note you add creates potential connections Each connection strengthens understanding Stronger understanding leads to better notes Better notes attract more connections This creates a positive feedback loop where your knowledge base becomes increasingly useful.

The Zettelkasten (“slip box” in German) is a note-taking method that transforms how you think and write. Developed by sociologist Niklas Luhmann, who used it to write over 70 books, the system creates a network of interconnected ideas. 01 (sidenote: 01 Luhmann maintained his Zettelkasten on paper index cards. Modern digital tools make the method even more powerful. ) Why Zettelkasten? Most note-taking systems fail because they’re designed for storage, not thinking. You capture information, file it away, and never see it again.
The Zettelkasten is different. It’s designed for:
Connection: Every note links to others Emergence: Ideas combine in unexpected ways Growth: The system becomes more valuable over time Start Small You don’t need thousands of notes to benefit. Even 20-30 well-connected notes create useful emergence. Core Principles 1. Atomic Notes Each note should contain exactly one idea. See [[The Atomic Notes Principle]] for why this constraint is liberating, not limiting.
2. Write for Your Future Self Don’t just copy quotes. Write in your own words, as if explaining to someone unfamiliar with the source. This forces understanding.
3. Link Liberally Every note should link to at least one other note. These connections are where the magic happens. See [[Bidirectional Linking]] for how backlinks enable discovery.
Getting Started Pick a tool: This site uses Hugo with wikilinks. Obsidian, Roam, and others work too. Start with what interests you: Don’t try to build a comprehensive system. Follow curiosity. Create your first MOC: A [[Note-Taking|Map of Content]] organizes related notes. Review regularly: [[Spaced Repetition]] keeps knowledge fresh. No Perfect System The best system is one you’ll actually use. Don’t over-engineer. Start writing, and evolve your approach over time. Common Mistakes Over-categorizing: Tags and folders are less important than links. 04 (sidenote: 04 Luhmann famously said his Zettelkasten was his “second brain” - not a filing cabinet. ) Collecting without processing: Capture is easy; thinking is hard. See [[Progressive Summarization]] for a method to process notes over time.
Expecting immediate results: The value compounds. Give it time.
Next Steps Explore the [[Note-Taking]] map to dive deeper into specific techniques. Or browse the knowledge graph to see how ideas connect.

In 1945, Vannevar Bush published “As We May Think” in The Atlantic, describing the Memex - a hypothetical device for storing and linking personal knowledge.
The Memex Vision Bush imagined a desk-sized device containing:
Microfilm storage of all books and records A mechanism to add personal annotations The ability to create trails between related items “The human mind operates by association. With one item in its grasp, it snaps instantly to the next that is suggested by the association of thoughts.”
The trail-making capability is remarkably similar to modern [[Bidirectional Linking]].
Prescient Ideas Bush anticipated:
Hypertext: Linking between documents Personal knowledge bases: Individual collections of information Associative retrieval: Finding by connection, not location He recognized that hierarchical organization (like library classification) doesn’t match how we think.
Historical Context Written as WWII ended, Bush was reflecting on how scientific knowledge had exploded during the war. He worried about researchers drowning in publications, unable to find relevant prior work.
Connection to Modern Systems The Memex directly inspired:
Ted Nelson’s Xanadu project Douglas Engelbart’s NLS The World Wide Web Modern PKM tools like Roam, Obsidian, and this [[Note-Taking|system]] Bush’s vision took 75 years to become practical. We now have the tools he imagined - the question is whether we use them effectively.
See [[How to Take Smart Notes]] for a practical methodology that fulfills Bush’s vision.
title: As We May Think

contents:
How to Take Smart Notes by Sönke Ahrens introduces Niklas Luhmann’s Zettelkasten method to a modern audience. Luhmann, a German sociologist, wrote over 70 books and 400 articles using this system.
Key Concepts The Slip-Box System Luhmann maintained two slip-boxes:
Bibliographical box: Quick references to sources Main box: His own ideas and connections The main box is where the magic happens. Each note is:
Written in complete sentences Self-contained and understandable in isolation Connected to existing notes via explicit links Writing as Thinking Ahrens argues that writing is not the output of thinking but the medium of thinking. The act of writing forces clarity.
“The slip-box is designed to present you with ideas you have already forgotten.”
Bottom-Up Organization Unlike traditional outlines (top-down), the Zettelkasten grows organically. Structure emerges from connections, not predetermined categories.
Application The book’s insights directly inform:
[[The Atomic Notes Principle]] - One idea per note [[Evergreen Notes]] - Notes that grow over time [[Bidirectional Linking]] - Connection-based structure My Takeaways The most valuable insight: write notes for your future self, not to document what you read. Every note should be phrased as if explaining to someone unfamiliar with the source.
This shifts note-taking from passive capture to active synthesis.
title: How to Take Smart Notes

Progressive summarization is Tiago Forte’s method for extracting value from notes over time. Instead of processing everything upfront, you distill notes progressively as you use them.
The Layers Each pass adds a layer of highlighting:
Layer 0: Original content (capture) Layer 1: Bold the most interesting passages Layer 2: Highlight the bolded passages that stand out Layer 3: Write a brief summary at the top Layer 4: Remix into your own original content
You don’t apply all layers immediately. Each layer is added when you revisit the note for a specific purpose.
Just-in-Time Processing The key insight: don’t process notes until you need them. Most captured content is never used. Progressive summarization ensures you only invest effort in notes that prove valuable.
This connects to [[Spaced Repetition]]: each revisit is an opportunity for both review and distillation.
Relationship to Zettelkasten Progressive summarization is compatible with the [[The Atomic Notes Principle|atomic notes principle]]. As you distill a note to its essence, you might extract multiple atomic notes from the highlights.
It bridges the gap between quick capture and [[Evergreen Notes]]:
Capture quickly (fleeting notes) Progressively distill over time Extract permanent atomic notes when insights crystallize Practical Application Start with Layer 1 on everything you capture. Add deeper layers only when you return to a note. Let future you decide what’s truly valuable.
See [[How to Take Smart Notes]] for the original Zettelkasten approach that influenced this method.
title: Progressive Summarization

contents:
Spaced repetition is a learning technique based on the spacing effect: we remember things better when we review them at increasing intervals rather than cramming.
The Science When you learn something new, the memory decays over time. Each review strengthens the memory and slows the decay rate. By timing reviews just before you’d forget, you maximize retention with minimum effort.
The optimal intervals follow a pattern:
First review: 1 day Second review: 3 days Third review: 7 days Fourth review: 14 days And so on, roughly doubling each time Application to Note-Taking Spaced repetition complements [[Evergreen Notes]] naturally. Each time you revisit a note to add links or refine content, you’re reinforcing that knowledge.
The [[Note-Taking|knowledge graph]] can guide your reviews. Notes with many connections are naturally reviewed more often as you traverse the graph. Orphan notes might need deliberate scheduling.
Tools and Systems Dedicated SRS tools like Anki automate interval scheduling. But even without special software, the principle applies:
Revisit notes periodically Use daily notes to reference older concepts Let curiosity guide exploratory sessions Connection to Writing Writing itself is a form of retrieval practice. When you write about a concept in your own words, you’re testing and strengthening your understanding.
See [[Progressive Summarization]] for a method that naturally incorporates spaced review.
title: Spaced Repetition

Bidirectional linking means that when note A links to note B, note B automatically knows about and displays the connection back to A. This simple mechanism transforms how we navigate and discover knowledge.
Why Backlinks Matter Traditional links are one-way streets. You know where you’re going, but you can’t see where you came from. Backlinks complete the picture.
Consider a note about “Machine Learning”. Without backlinks, you only see what ML links to. With backlinks, you discover:
Projects that use ML Problems ML might solve Related concepts you’ve explored This serendipitous discovery is impossible with one-way links.
Enabling Discovery Backlinks surface unexpected connections. When you create a note about a new concept and see it already has backlinks, you’ve discovered relationships you didn’t consciously make.
This is the essence of networked thought: the whole becomes greater than the sum of its parts.
Implementation In this system, backlinks appear automatically at the bottom of each note. They show:
The linking note’s title Context around the link A direct path to explore further Foundation for Graphs Bidirectional links enable the [[Note-Taking|knowledge graph visualization]]. Each bidirectional link becomes an edge in the graph, making your knowledge structure visible and navigable.
See also:

contents:
The knowledge graph visualizes connections between notes. It turns the abstract idea of “linked thinking” into something you can see and explore.
Why Visualize? Our brains are visual. A list of backlinks tells you what connects, but a graph shows you how the connections form patterns.
Try It Open the full-page graph to explore. Drag nodes, filter by section, toggle link types. How It Works The graph uses D3.js force simulation. Each note becomes a node; each link becomes an edge.
const simulation = d3.forceSimulation(nodes) .force('link', d3.forceLink(links).id(d => d.id)) .force('charge', d3.forceManyBody().strength(-200)) .force('center', d3.forceCenter(width / 2, height / 2)); Nodes repel each other (charge force) while links pull connected nodes together. The result is a layout where clusters naturally emerge.
Two Types of Edges The graph shows two kinds of connections:
Direct links (solid blue): Explicit wikilinks between notes. These are intentional connections you create.
Tag connections (dashed gray): Notes sharing the same tag. These are implicit - they suggest possible relationships you might not have noticed.
Technical Detail: Edge Detection Direct links are detected by scanning note content for [[...]] patterns and wikilink shortcodes. This happens at build time, so the graph data is static and fast to load.
{{- $bracketMatches := findRE `\[\[([^\]|]+)` $content -}} Reading the Graph Clusters indicate related concepts. The [[Note-Taking]] and [[Learning]] nodes should be close together, connected by shared notes.
Hubs are highly-connected nodes. MOCs like [[Note-Taking]] naturally become hubs because they link to many notes.
Bridges connect different clusters. A note that links learning concepts to technical implementations bridges those domains.
Filtering The full-page graph offers controls to:
Show/hide sections (articles, notes, projects) Toggle direct links vs tag connections Search for specific notes Zoom in on details This makes large graphs manageable while preserving the overall structure.
Limitations The graph is a model, not reality. It shows explicit connections but not the implicit understanding in your head.
Use it as a tool for discovery, not a measure of knowledge completeness.
Building Your Own The graph is generated entirely in Hugo templates. No external build step required. Check the theme’s partials/graph.html for implementation details.

Evergreen notes are notes designed to grow and improve over time. Unlike fleeting captures or project-specific documentation, evergreen notes are investments in your future thinking.
Characteristics Concept-oriented: Written about ideas, not sources or events. A note titled “Spaced Repetition” is evergreen; “Notes from Chapter 3” is not.
Densely linked: Connected to many other notes, forming a web of knowledge. Each new connection adds context and value.
Written for yourself: In your own words, reflecting your understanding. Not quotes or summaries, but synthesis.
The Compound Effect Like compound interest, evergreen notes become more valuable over time:
Each note you add creates potential connections Each connection strengthens understanding Stronger understanding leads to better notes Better notes attract more connections This creates a positive feedback loop where your knowledge base becomes increasingly useful.

The Zettelkasten (“slip box” in German) is a note-taking method that transforms how you think and write. Developed by sociologist Niklas Luhmann, who used it to write over 70 books, the system creates a network of interconnected ideas. 01 (sidenote: 01 Luhmann maintained his Zettelkasten on paper index cards. Modern digital tools make the method even more powerful. ) Why Zettelkasten? Most note-taking systems fail because they’re designed for storage, not thinking. You capture information, file it away, and never see it again.
The Zettelkasten is different. It’s designed for:
Connection: Every note links to others Emergence: Ideas combine in unexpected ways Growth: The system becomes more valuable over time Start Small You don’t need thousands of notes to benefit. Even 20-30 well-connected notes create useful emergence. Core Principles 1. Atomic Notes Each note should contain exactly one idea. See [[The Atomic Notes Principle]] for why this constraint is liberating, not limiting.
2. Write for Your Future Self Don’t just copy quotes. Write in your own words, as if explaining to someone unfamiliar with the source. This forces understanding.
3. Link Liberally Every note should link to at least one other note. These connections are where the magic happens. See [[Bidirectional Linking]] for how backlinks enable discovery.
Getting Started Pick a tool: This site uses Hugo with wikilinks. Obsidian, Roam, and others work too. Start with what interests you: Don’t try to build a comprehensive system. Follow curiosity. Create your first MOC: A [[Note-Taking|Map of Content]] organizes related notes. Review regularly: [[Spaced Repetition]] keeps knowledge fresh. No Perfect System The best system is one you’ll actually use. Don’t over-engineer. Start writing, and evolve your approach over time. Common Mistakes Over-categorizing: Tags and folders are less important than links. 04 (sidenote: 04 Luhmann famously said his Zettelkasten was his “second brain” - not a filing cabinet. ) Collecting without processing: Capture is easy; thinking is hard. See [[Progressive Summarization]] for a method to process notes over time.
Expecting immediate results: The value compounds. Give it time.
Next Steps Explore the [[Note-Taking]] map to dive deeper into specific techniques. Or browse the knowledge graph to see how ideas connect.

In 1945, Vannevar Bush published “As We May Think” in The Atlantic, describing the Memex - a hypothetical device for storing and linking personal knowledge.
The Memex Vision Bush imagined a desk-sized device containing:
Microfilm storage of all books and records A mechanism to add personal annotations The ability to create trails between related items “The human mind operates by association. With one item in its grasp, it snaps instantly to the next that is suggested by the association of thoughts.”
The trail-making capability is remarkably similar to modern [[Bidirectional Linking]].
Prescient Ideas Bush anticipated:
Hypertext: Linking between documents Personal knowledge bases: Individual collections of information Associative retrieval: Finding by connection, not location He recognized that hierarchical organization (like library classification) doesn’t match how we think.
Historical Context Written as WWII ended, Bush was reflecting on how scientific knowledge had exploded during the war. He worried about researchers drowning in publications, unable to find relevant prior work.
Connection to Modern Systems The Memex directly inspired:
Ted Nelson’s Xanadu project Douglas Engelbart’s NLS The World Wide Web Modern PKM tools like Roam, Obsidian, and this [[Note-Taking|system]] Bush’s vision took 75 years to become practical. We now have the tools he imagined - the question is whether we use them effectively.
See [[How to Take Smart Notes]] for a practical methodology that fulfills Bush’s vision.
title: As We May Think

contents:
How to Take Smart Notes by Sönke Ahrens introduces Niklas Luhmann’s Zettelkasten method to a modern audience. Luhmann, a German sociologist, wrote over 70 books and 400 articles using this system.
Key Concepts The Slip-Box System Luhmann maintained two slip-boxes:
Bibliographical box: Quick references to sources Main box: His own ideas and connections The main box is where the magic happens. Each note is:
Written in complete sentences Self-contained and understandable in isolation Connected to existing notes via explicit links Writing as Thinking Ahrens argues that writing is not the output of thinking but the medium of thinking. The act of writing forces clarity.
“The slip-box is designed to present you with ideas you have already forgotten.”
Bottom-Up Organization Unlike traditional outlines (top-down), the Zettelkasten grows organically. Structure emerges from connections, not predetermined categories.
Application The book’s insights directly inform:
[[The Atomic Notes Principle]] - One idea per note [[Evergreen Notes]] - Notes that grow over time [[Bidirectional Linking]] - Connection-based structure My Takeaways The most valuable insight: write notes for your future self, not to document what you read. Every note should be phrased as if explaining to someone unfamiliar with the source.
This shifts note-taking from passive capture to active synthesis.
title: How to Take Smart Notes

Progressive summarization is Tiago Forte’s method for extracting value from notes over time. Instead of processing everything upfront, you distill notes progressively as you use them.
The Layers Each pass adds a layer of highlighting:
Layer 0: Original content (capture) Layer 1: Bold the most interesting passages Layer 2: Highlight the bolded passages that stand out Layer 3: Write a brief summary at the top Layer 4: Remix into your own original content
You don’t apply all layers immediately. Each layer is added when you revisit the note for a specific purpose.
Just-in-Time Processing The key insight: don’t process notes until you need them. Most captured content is never used. Progressive summarization ensures you only invest effort in notes that prove valuable.
This connects to [[Spaced Repetition]]: each revisit is an opportunity for both review and distillation.
Relationship to Zettelkasten Progressive summarization is compatible with the [[The Atomic Notes Principle|atomic notes principle]]. As you distill a note to its essence, you might extract multiple atomic notes from the highlights.
It bridges the gap between quick capture and [[Evergreen Notes]]:
Capture quickly (fleeting notes) Progressively distill over time Extract permanent atomic notes when insights crystallize Practical Application Start with Layer 1 on everything you capture. Add deeper layers only when you return to a note. Let future you decide what’s truly valuable.
See [[How to Take Smart Notes]] for the original Zettelkasten approach that influenced this method.

Spaced repetition is a learning technique based on the spacing effect: we remember things better when we review them at increasing intervals rather than cramming.
The Science When you learn something new, the memory decays over time. Each review strengthens the memory and slows the decay rate. By timing reviews just before you’d forget, you maximize retention with minimum effort.
The optimal intervals follow a pattern:
First review: 1 day Second review: 3 days Third review: 7 days Fourth review: 14 days And so on, roughly doubling each time Application to Note-Taking Spaced repetition complements [[Evergreen Notes]] naturally. Each time you revisit a note to add links or refine content, you’re reinforcing that knowledge.
The [[Note-Taking|knowledge graph]] can guide your reviews. Notes with many connections are naturally reviewed more often as you traverse the graph. Orphan notes might need deliberate scheduling.
Tools and Systems Dedicated SRS tools like Anki automate interval scheduling. But even without special software, the principle applies:
Revisit notes periodically Use daily notes to reference older concepts Let curiosity guide exploratory sessions Connection to Writing Writing itself is a form of retrieval practice. When you write about a concept in your own words, you’re testing and strengthening your understanding.
See [[Progressive Summarization]] for a method that naturally incorporates spaced review.

Bidirectional linking means that when note A links to note B, note B automatically knows about and displays the connection back to A. This simple mechanism transforms how we navigate and discover knowledge.
Why Backlinks Matter Traditional links are one-way streets. You know where you’re going, but you can’t see where you came from. Backlinks complete the picture.
Consider a note about “Machine Learning”. Without backlinks, you only see what ML links to. With backlinks, you discover:
Projects that use ML Problems ML might solve Related concepts you’ve explored This serendipitous discovery is impossible with one-way links.
Enabling Discovery Backlinks surface unexpected connections. When you create a note about a new concept and see it already has backlinks, you’ve discovered relationships you didn’t consciously make.
This is the essence of networked thought: the whole becomes greater than the sum of its parts.

Direct links (solid blue): Explicit wikilinks between notes. These are intentional connections you create.

The Zettelkasten (“slip box” in German) is a note-taking method that transforms how you think and write. Developed by sociologist Niklas Luhmann, who used it to write over 70 books, the system creates a network of interconnected ideas. 01 (sidenote: 01 Luhmann maintained his Zettelkasten on paper index cards. Modern digital tools make the method even more powerful. ) Why Zettelkasten? Most note-taking systems fail because they’re designed for storage, not thinking. You capture information, file it away, and never see it again.
The Zettelkasten is different. It’s designed for:
Connection: Every note links to others Emergence: Ideas combine in unexpected ways Growth: The system becomes more valuable over time Start Small You don’t need thousands of notes to benefit. Even 20-30 well-connected notes create useful emergence. Core Principles 1. Atomic Notes Each note should contain exactly one idea. See [[The Atomic Notes Principle]] for why this constraint is liberating, not limiting.
2. Write for Your Future Self Don’t just copy quotes. Write in your own words, as if explaining to someone unfamiliar with the source. This forces understanding.
3. Link Liberally Every note should link to at least one other note. These connections are where the magic happens. See [[Bidirectional Linking]] for how backlinks enable discovery.

Create your first MOC: A [[Note-Taking|Map of Content]] organizes related notes. Review regularly: [[Spaced Repetition]] keeps knowledge fresh. No Perfect System The best system is one you’ll actually use. Don’t over-engineer. Start writing, and evolve your approach over time. Common Mistakes Over-categorizing: Tags and folders are less important than links. 04 (sidenote: 04 Luhmann famously said his Zettelkasten was his “second brain” - not a filing cabinet. ) Collecting without processing: Capture is easy; thinking is hard. See [[Progressive Summarization]] for a method to process notes over time.
Expecting immediate results: The value compounds. Give it time.

In 1945, Vannevar Bush published “As We May Think” in The Atlantic, describing the Memex - a hypothetical device for storing and linking personal knowledge.
The Memex Vision Bush imagined a desk-sized device containing:
Microfilm storage of all books and records A mechanism to add personal annotations The ability to create trails between related items “The human mind operates by association. With one item in its grasp, it snaps instantly to the next that is suggested by the association of thoughts.”
The trail-making capability is remarkably similar to modern [[Bidirectional Linking]].
Prescient Ideas Bush anticipated:
Hypertext: Linking between documents Personal knowledge bases: Individual collections of information Associative retrieval: Finding by connection, not location He recognized that hierarchical organization (like library classification) doesn’t match how we think.
Historical Context Written as WWII ended, Bush was reflecting on how scientific knowledge had exploded during the war. He worried about researchers drowning in publications, unable to find relevant prior work.
Connection to Modern Systems The Memex directly inspired:
Ted Nelson’s Xanadu project Douglas Engelbart’s NLS The World Wide Web Modern PKM tools like Roam, Obsidian, and this [[Note-Taking|system]] Bush’s vision took 75 years to become practical. We now have the tools he imagined - the question is whether we use them effectively.
See [[How to Take Smart Notes]] for a practical methodology that fulfills Bush’s vision.

How to Take Smart Notes by Sönke Ahrens introduces Niklas Luhmann’s Zettelkasten method to a modern audience. Luhmann, a German sociologist, wrote over 70 books and 400 articles using this system.
Key Concepts The Slip-Box System Luhmann maintained two slip-boxes:
Bibliographical box: Quick references to sources Main box: His own ideas and connections The main box is where the magic happens. Each note is:
Written in complete sentences Self-contained and understandable in isolation Connected to existing notes via explicit links Writing as Thinking Ahrens argues that writing is not the output of thinking but the medium of thinking. The act of writing forces clarity.
“The slip-box is designed to present you with ideas you have already forgotten.”
Bottom-Up Organization Unlike traditional outlines (top-down), the Zettelkasten grows organically. Structure emerges from connections, not predetermined categories.
Application The book’s insights directly inform:
[[The Atomic Notes Principle]] - One idea per note [[Evergreen Notes]] - Notes that grow over time [[Bidirectional Linking]] - Connection-based structure My Takeaways The most valuable insight: write notes for your future self, not to document what you read. Every note should be phrased as if explaining to someone unfamiliar with the source.
This shifts note-taking from passive capture to active synthesis.

Bidirectional linking means that when note A links to note B, note B automatically knows about and displays the connection back to A. This simple mechanism transforms how we navigate and discover knowledge.
Why Backlinks Matter Traditional links are one-way streets. You know where you’re going, but you can’t see where you came from. Backlinks complete the picture.
Consider a note about “Machine Learning”. Without backlinks, you only see what ML links to. With backlinks, you discover:
Projects that use ML Problems ML might solve Related concepts you’ve explored This serendipitous discovery is impossible with one-way links.
Enabling Discovery Backlinks surface unexpected connections. When you create a note about a new concept and see it already has backlinks, you’ve discovered relationships you didn’t consciously make.
This is the essence of networked thought: the whole becomes greater than the sum of its parts.
Implementation In this system, backlinks appear automatically at the bottom of each note. They show:
The linking note’s title Context around the link A direct path to explore further Foundation for Graphs Bidirectional links enable the [[Note-Taking|knowledge graph visualization]]. Each bidirectional link becomes an edge in the graph, making your knowledge structure visible and navigable.

The Zettelkasten (“slip box” in German) is a note-taking method that transforms how you think and write. Developed by sociologist Niklas Luhmann, who used it to write over 70 books, the system creates a network of interconnected ideas. 01 (sidenote: 01 Luhmann maintained his Zettelkasten on paper index cards. Modern digital tools make the method even more powerful. ) Why Zettelkasten? Most note-taking systems fail because they’re designed for storage, not thinking. You capture information, file it away, and never see it again.
The Zettelkasten is different. It’s designed for:
Connection: Every note links to others Emergence: Ideas combine in unexpected ways Growth: The system becomes more valuable over time Start Small You don’t need thousands of notes to benefit. Even 20-30 well-connected notes create useful emergence. Core Principles 1. Atomic Notes Each note should contain exactly one idea. See [[The Atomic Notes Principle]] for why this constraint is liberating, not limiting.
2. Write for Your Future Self Don’t just copy quotes. Write in your own words, as if explaining to someone unfamiliar with the source. This forces understanding.

Create your first MOC: A [[Note-Taking|Map of Content]] organizes related notes. Review regularly: [[Spaced Repetition]] keeps knowledge fresh. No Perfect System The best system is one you’ll actually use. Don’t over-engineer. Start writing, and evolve your approach over time. Common Mistakes Over-categorizing: Tags and folders are less important than links. 04 (sidenote: 04 Luhmann famously said his Zettelkasten was his “second brain” - not a filing cabinet. ) Collecting without processing: Capture is easy; thinking is hard. See [[Progressive Summarization]] for a method to process notes over time.
Expecting immediate results: The value compounds. Give it time.

In 1945, Vannevar Bush published “As We May Think” in The Atlantic, describing the Memex - a hypothetical device for storing and linking personal knowledge.
The Memex Vision Bush imagined a desk-sized device containing:
Microfilm storage of all books and records A mechanism to add personal annotations The ability to create trails between related items “The human mind operates by association. With one item in its grasp, it snaps instantly to the next that is suggested by the association of thoughts.”
The trail-making capability is remarkably similar to modern [[Bidirectional Linking]].
Prescient Ideas Bush anticipated:
Hypertext: Linking between documents Personal knowledge bases: Individual collections of information Associative retrieval: Finding by connection, not location He recognized that hierarchical organization (like library classification) doesn’t match how we think.
Historical Context Written as WWII ended, Bush was reflecting on how scientific knowledge had exploded during the war. He worried about researchers drowning in publications, unable to find relevant prior work.
Connection to Modern Systems The Memex directly inspired:
Ted Nelson’s Xanadu project Douglas Engelbart’s NLS The World Wide Web Modern PKM tools like Roam, Obsidian, and this [[Note-Taking|system]] Bush’s vision took 75 years to become practical. We now have the tools he imagined - the question is whether we use them effectively.
See [[How to Take Smart Notes]] for a practical methodology that fulfills Bush’s vision.

Written in complete sentences Self-contained and understandable in isolation Connected to existing notes via explicit links Writing as Thinking Ahrens argues that writing is not the output of thinking but the medium of thinking. The act of writing forces clarity.

Progressive summarization is Tiago Forte’s method for extracting value from notes over time. Instead of processing everything upfront, you distill notes progressively as you use them.
The Layers Each pass adds a layer of highlighting:
Layer 0: Original content (capture) Layer 1: Bold the most interesting passages Layer 2: Highlight the bolded passages that stand out Layer 3: Write a brief summary at the top Layer 4: Remix into your own original content
You don’t apply all layers immediately. Each layer is added when you revisit the note for a specific purpose.
Just-in-Time Processing The key insight: don’t process notes until you need them. Most captured content is never used. Progressive summarization ensures you only invest effort in notes that prove valuable.
This connects to [[Spaced Repetition]]: each revisit is an opportunity for both review and distillation.
Relationship to Zettelkasten Progressive summarization is compatible with the [[The Atomic Notes Principle|atomic notes principle]]. As you distill a note to its essence, you might extract multiple atomic notes from the highlights.
It bridges the gap between quick capture and [[Evergreen Notes]]:
Capture quickly (fleeting notes) Progressively distill over time Extract permanent atomic notes when insights crystallize Practical Application Start with Layer 1 on everything you capture. Add deeper layers only when you return to a note. Let future you decide what’s truly valuable.
See [[How to Take Smart Notes]] for the original Zettelkasten approach that influenced this method.

The Zettelkasten (“slip box” in German) is a note-taking method that transforms how you think and write. Developed by sociologist Niklas Luhmann, who used it to write over 70 books, the system creates a network of interconnected ideas. 01 (sidenote: 01 Luhmann maintained his Zettelkasten on paper index cards. Modern digital tools make the method even more powerful. ) Why Zettelkasten? Most note-taking systems fail because they’re designed for storage, not thinking. You capture information, file it away, and never see it again.
The Zettelkasten is different. It’s designed for:
Connection: Every note links to others Emergence: Ideas combine in unexpected ways Growth: The system becomes more valuable over time Start Small You don’t need thousands of notes to benefit. Even 20-30 well-connected notes create useful emergence. Core Principles 1. Atomic Notes Each note should contain exactly one idea. See [[The Atomic Notes Principle]] for why this constraint is liberating, not limiting.
2. Write for Your Future Self Don’t just copy quotes. Write in your own words, as if explaining to someone unfamiliar with the source. This forces understanding.
3. Link Liberally Every note should link to at least one other note. These connections are where the magic happens. See [[Bidirectional Linking]] for how backlinks enable discovery.

Create your first MOC: A [[Note-Taking|Map of Content]] organizes related notes. Review regularly: [[Spaced Repetition]] keeps knowledge fresh. No Perfect System The best system is one you’ll actually use. Don’t over-engineer. Start writing, and evolve your approach over time. Common Mistakes Over-categorizing: Tags and folders are less important than links. 04 (sidenote: 04 Luhmann famously said his Zettelkasten was his “second brain” - not a filing cabinet. ) Collecting without processing: Capture is easy; thinking is hard. See [[Progressive Summarization]] for a method to process notes over time.
Expecting immediate results: The value compounds. Give it time.

In 1945, Vannevar Bush published “As We May Think” in The Atlantic, describing the Memex - a hypothetical device for storing and linking personal knowledge.
The Memex Vision Bush imagined a desk-sized device containing:
Microfilm storage of all books and records A mechanism to add personal annotations The ability to create trails between related items “The human mind operates by association. With one item in its grasp, it snaps instantly to the next that is suggested by the association of thoughts.”
The trail-making capability is remarkably similar to modern [[Bidirectional Linking]].
Prescient Ideas Bush anticipated:
Hypertext: Linking between documents Personal knowledge bases: Individual collections of information Associative retrieval: Finding by connection, not location He recognized that hierarchical organization (like library classification) doesn’t match how we think.
Historical Context Written as WWII ended, Bush was reflecting on how scientific knowledge had exploded during the war. He worried about researchers drowning in publications, unable to find relevant prior work.
Connection to Modern Systems The Memex directly inspired:
Ted Nelson’s Xanadu project Douglas Engelbart’s NLS The World Wide Web Modern PKM tools like Roam, Obsidian, and this [[Note-Taking|system]] Bush’s vision took 75 years to become practical. We now have the tools he imagined - the question is whether we use them effectively.
See [[How to Take Smart Notes]] for a practical methodology that fulfills Bush’s vision.

Bibliographical box: Quick references to sources Main box: His own ideas and connections The main box is where the magic happens. Each note is:

contents:
Progressive summarization is Tiago Forte’s method for extracting value from notes over time. Instead of processing everything upfront, you distill notes progressively as you use them.
The Layers Each pass adds a layer of highlighting:
Layer 0: Original content (capture) Layer 1: Bold the most interesting passages Layer 2: Highlight the bolded passages that stand out Layer 3: Write a brief summary at the top Layer 4: Remix into your own original content
You don’t apply all layers immediately. Each layer is added when you revisit the note for a specific purpose.
Just-in-Time Processing The key insight: don’t process notes until you need them. Most captured content is never used. Progressive summarization ensures you only invest effort in notes that prove valuable.
This connects to [[Spaced Repetition]]: each revisit is an opportunity for both review and distillation.
Relationship to Zettelkasten Progressive summarization is compatible with the [[The Atomic Notes Principle|atomic notes principle]]. As you distill a note to its essence, you might extract multiple atomic notes from the highlights.
It bridges the gap between quick capture and [[Evergreen Notes]]:
Capture quickly (fleeting notes) Progressively distill over time Extract permanent atomic notes when insights crystallize Practical Application Start with Layer 1 on everything you capture. Add deeper layers only when you return to a note. Let future you decide what’s truly valuable.
See [[How to Take Smart Notes]] for the original Zettelkasten approach that influenced this method.

contents:
Spaced repetition is a learning technique based on the spacing effect: we remember things better when we review them at increasing intervals rather than cramming.
The Science When you learn something new, the memory decays over time. Each review strengthens the memory and slows the decay rate. By timing reviews just before you’d forget, you maximize retention with minimum effort.
The optimal intervals follow a pattern:
First review: 1 day Second review: 3 days Third review: 7 days Fourth review: 14 days And so on, roughly doubling each time Application to Note-Taking Spaced repetition complements [[Evergreen Notes]] naturally. Each time you revisit a note to add links or refine content, you’re reinforcing that knowledge.
The [[Note-Taking|knowledge graph]] can guide your reviews. Notes with many connections are naturally reviewed more often as you traverse the graph. Orphan notes might need deliberate scheduling.
Tools and Systems Dedicated SRS tools like Anki automate interval scheduling. But even without special software, the principle applies:
Revisit notes periodically Use daily notes to reference older concepts Let curiosity guide exploratory sessions Connection to Writing Writing itself is a form of retrieval practice. When you write about a concept in your own words, you’re testing and strengthening your understanding.
See [[Progressive Summarization]] for a method that naturally incorporates spaced review.

Bidirectional linking means that when note A links to note B, note B automatically knows about and displays the connection back to A. This simple mechanism transforms how we navigate and discover knowledge.
Why Backlinks Matter Traditional links are one-way streets. You know where you’re going, but you can’t see where you came from. Backlinks complete the picture.
Consider a note about “Machine Learning”. Without backlinks, you only see what ML links to. With backlinks, you discover:
Projects that use ML Problems ML might solve Related concepts you’ve explored This serendipitous discovery is impossible with one-way links.
Enabling Discovery Backlinks surface unexpected connections. When you create a note about a new concept and see it already has backlinks, you’ve discovered relationships you didn’t consciously make.
This is the essence of networked thought: the whole becomes greater than the sum of its parts.
Implementation In this system, backlinks appear automatically at the bottom of each note. They show:
The linking note’s title Context around the link A direct path to explore further Foundation for Graphs Bidirectional links enable the [[Note-Taking|knowledge graph visualization]]. Each bidirectional link becomes an edge in the graph, making your knowledge structure visible and navigable.

The Zettelkasten is different. It’s designed for:
Connection: Every note links to others Emergence: Ideas combine in unexpected ways Growth: The system becomes more valuable over time Start Small You don’t need thousands of notes to benefit. Even 20-30 well-connected notes create useful emergence. Core Principles 1. Atomic Notes Each note should contain exactly one idea. See [[The Atomic Notes Principle]] for why this constraint is liberating, not limiting.
2. Write for Your Future Self Don’t just copy quotes. Write in your own words, as if explaining to someone unfamiliar with the source. This forces understanding.
3. Link Liberally Every note should link to at least one other note. These connections are where the magic happens. See [[Bidirectional Linking]] for how backlinks enable discovery.
Getting Started Pick a tool: This site uses Hugo with wikilinks. Obsidian, Roam, and others work too. Start with what interests you: Don’t try to build a comprehensive system. Follow curiosity. Create your first MOC: A [[Note-Taking|Map of Content]] organizes related notes. Review regularly: [[Spaced Repetition]] keeps knowledge fresh. No Perfect System The best system is one you’ll actually use. Don’t over-engineer. Start writing, and evolve your approach over time. Common Mistakes Over-categorizing: Tags and folders are less important than links. 04 (sidenote: 04 Luhmann famously said his Zettelkasten was his “second brain” - not a filing cabinet. ) Collecting without processing: Capture is easy; thinking is hard. See [[Progressive Summarization]] for a method to process notes over time.
Expecting immediate results: The value compounds. Give it time.
Next Steps Explore the [[Note-Taking]] map to dive deeper into specific techniques. Or browse the knowledge graph to see how ideas connect.

In 1945, Vannevar Bush published “As We May Think” in The Atlantic, describing the Memex - a hypothetical device for storing and linking personal knowledge.
The Memex Vision Bush imagined a desk-sized device containing:
Microfilm storage of all books and records A mechanism to add personal annotations The ability to create trails between related items “The human mind operates by association. With one item in its grasp, it snaps instantly to the next that is suggested by the association of thoughts.”
The trail-making capability is remarkably similar to modern [[Bidirectional Linking]].
Prescient Ideas Bush anticipated:
Hypertext: Linking between documents Personal knowledge bases: Individual collections of information Associative retrieval: Finding by connection, not location He recognized that hierarchical organization (like library classification) doesn’t match how we think.
Historical Context Written as WWII ended, Bush was reflecting on how scientific knowledge had exploded during the war. He worried about researchers drowning in publications, unable to find relevant prior work.
Connection to Modern Systems The Memex directly inspired:
Ted Nelson’s Xanadu project Douglas Engelbart’s NLS The World Wide Web Modern PKM tools like Roam, Obsidian, and this [[Note-Taking|system]] Bush’s vision took 75 years to become practical. We now have the tools he imagined - the question is whether we use them effectively.
See [[How to Take Smart Notes]] for a practical methodology that fulfills Bush’s vision.
title: As We May Think

contents:
How to Take Smart Notes by Sönke Ahrens introduces Niklas Luhmann’s Zettelkasten method to a modern audience. Luhmann, a German sociologist, wrote over 70 books and 400 articles using this system.
Key Concepts The Slip-Box System Luhmann maintained two slip-boxes:
Bibliographical box: Quick references to sources Main box: His own ideas and connections The main box is where the magic happens. Each note is:
Written in complete sentences Self-contained and understandable in isolation Connected to existing notes via explicit links Writing as Thinking Ahrens argues that writing is not the output of thinking but the medium of thinking. The act of writing forces clarity.
“The slip-box is designed to present you with ideas you have already forgotten.”
Bottom-Up Organization Unlike traditional outlines (top-down), the Zettelkasten grows organically. Structure emerges from connections, not predetermined categories.
Application The book’s insights directly inform:
[[The Atomic Notes Principle]] - One idea per note [[Evergreen Notes]] - Notes that grow over time [[Bidirectional Linking]] - Connection-based structure My Takeaways The most valuable insight: write notes for your future self, not to document what you read. Every note should be phrased as if explaining to someone unfamiliar with the source.
This shifts note-taking from passive capture to active synthesis.
